title: FRQ2_CO2 effects on chloroplasts and mitochondria

content.question:
Read each question carefully. Write your response in the space provided for each part of each question. Answers must be written out in paragraph form. Outlines, bulleted lists, or diagrams alone are not acceptable and will not be scored.

Elevated levels of <math alttext="C O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>CO</mtext><mn>2</mn></msub></math> increase the rate of photosynthesis and growth in plants. Scientists studying the mechanisms involved in these increases examined a variety of species and found that when plants are exposed to elevated levels of <math alttext="C O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>CO</mtext><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, there is an increase in the number of chloroplasts per cell. To investigate whether the elevated levels of <math alttext="C O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>CO</mtext><mn>2</mn></msub></math> have a similar effect on the number of mitochondria in plant cells, the scientists then selected six of these species to quantify the number of mitochondria per cell when the plants were exposed to both normal and elevated levels of <math alttext="C O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>CO</mtext><mn>2</mn></msub></math> (Table 1).

Determine which species show(s) a difference in the number of mitochondria between normal and elevated levels of <math alttext="C O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>CO</mtext><mn>2</mn></msub></math>.

(c) Based on the data in Table 1, describe the relationship between the level of <math alttext="C O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>CO</mtext><mn>2</mn></msub></math> and the average number of mitochondria per unit area of a cell.

(d) The leaves of a particular plant species are typically green, but scientists notice a plant in which the leaves have white stripes. They determine that the stripes result from a mutation in mitochondrial <math alttext="D N A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>DNA</mi></math> that interferes with the development of chloroplasts. The scientists crossed plants using pollen from the plant with white-striped leaves and ovules from a plant with green leaves. Predict the phenotype(s) of the leaves of offspring produced from this cross. Provide reasoning to justify your prediction. Explain why plants with the same genotype are able to differ in the structure and/or number of certain organelles in response to changes in atmospheric levels of <math alttext="C O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>CO</mtext><mn>2</mn></msub></math>.
